pull.title: net: Document what happens to getdata of unknown type
pull.body: Any getdata of unknown type will never be processed and blocks all future messages from a peer. This isn't obviously clear from reading the code, so document it.

rename.from: net: Document what happens to getdata of unknonw type
rename.to: net: Document what happens to getdata of unknown type

net: Document what happens to getdata of unknonw type

events.message: net: Document what happens to getdata of unknonw type

events.body: ACK as well. This construction (upholding the connection with a peer we can never process a message from) doesn't make a lot of sense to me, but documenting it is good.
Yeah, I'd say to disconnect the peer, but that should be done in a follow-up pull request.
Looks right to me, but I haven't had a chance to verify that this is true with a test.

comments.body: Wouldn't this not only block future GetData, but also all other messages from this peer, because of the line `if (!pfrom->vRecvGetData.empty()) return true;` in `ProcessMessages()`?
Indeed. In which case we might actually disconnect the peer, since there isn't anything that could happen on that connection anyway.
This is also the only thing that prevents vRecvGetData from unbounded growth.
Perhaps I'd suggest adding this note to ``if (!pfrom->vRecvGetData.empty()) return true;``, otherwise it's not obvious why we should do this check before processing new messages.
The comment there reads `// this maintains the order of responses`
Which does not really explain that removing this line would enable DoS :)
